section.title: Overview
section.p:
NCC collects measurements for the following areas:
Diameter (Base) metrics
Diameter supplemental metrics
Device notification metrics
LDAP metrics
Surepay LDAP metrics
HTTP metrics
HTTP_3GPP metrics for 5G
Site Routing metrics
Rules metrics
Overload Metrics
Rating metrics
PCRF and PCF metrics
Entity count metrics
CDR metrics
Notification server metrics
NRF metrics
Data Refinery metrics
CDR streams metrics
section.note: Some of the metrics in the following tables are noted as being calculated by applying Prometheus rules on other collected metrics, demarcated by the phrase "(NCC telemetry package)". These are only available if the NCC Telemetry package is deployed, or if the operator implements these rules in their own Prometheus server. Nokia can provide these rules upon request.

note.p: For average_latency_last_interval, this is the change in latency over a configurable period of time, which can be increasing as well as decreasing. For example, using the diameter_inbound_sum and diameter_inbound_count metrics, the average_latency_last_ interval is calculated as follows:rate(diameter_outbound_sum[<period>]) / rate(diameter_outbound_count[<period>])

Where for example, in the last <period> (let’s say period of 5 minutes), the first value of diameter_inbound_sum is S1, and the last value of diameter_inbound_sum is S5. Then: "rate(diameter_inbound_sum[])" is equal to "(S5 - S1) / 300s" and in the last , the first value of "diameter_inbound_count" is C1, and the last value of "diameter_inbound_count" is C5. Then: "rate(diameter_inbound_count[5 minutes])" is equal to "(C5 - C1) / 300s" Then the average latency in the last 5 minutes is as follows:

The value of any of the count since last interval metrics is an extrapolated value and never an exact value. This behavior is from the way that Prometheus does the calculation. This is calculated using the increase( ) function; for example, increase(diameter_inbound_ count[10m]) or increase(ldap_count[10m]), etc. The "Increase()" function uses a minimum of two data points over a time period and based on these two data points a change in count since last interval value is calculated. Prometheus does an approximation because it calculates count since last interval in a fail safe way that is resistant to failures such as scrape miss, node restarts, etc.

The recommended value for last interval (default 10 minutes), should be at least twice that of the granularity period gen3gppxml/default_gran_period) defined in Gen3GPPXML tool. This is to ensure that the Gen3GPPXML tool, would be able to take the snapshot of count since last interval metrics at least once. For example, if the granularity period configured is 300s (5 minutes), you should configure the last interval window in count since last interval metrics as 10 minutes. See the “Gen3gppxml section” in the NCC Installation Guide for more information about these parameters.

When an incoming 5G message arrives at an NCC ME over HTTP/2, it may be siterouted to another home NCC ME. For example, consider a case where an incoming N7 request that first lands on ME 1 is site-routed to ME 2, which is the home for the device (PGW > ME1 > ME2). The metrics for this example are established as follows:
On ME1, http_3gpp_inbound metrics are pegged along with the site_routing metric pegged with the “InProtocol” label indicating “http_3gpp” and the “Decision” label indicating “message sent to primary”.
From ME1 to ME2, the message is forwarded using the Diameter protocol.
On ME2, the diameter_inbound metrics are pegged to set the “DiameterApp” label to N7 (for this example) to distinguish this from standard 4G Diameter messages received. The site_routing metric is then pegged with the “InProtocol” label indicating ‘http_3gpp’ and the “Decision” label indicating “processed locally”.

section.title: Diameter (Base) metrics
section.p: The base Diameter measurements record the number of Diameter messages in and out of NCC, the specific type of messages, the result of the message processing, and who was the peer. There are a number of labels within these measurements that provide a rich set of detailed information for understanding the behavior of the NCC Diameter interactions. These metrics are recorded on the ME Diameter Application pods.

See the following for Diameter base metrics:
“Diameter inbound metrics” describes the Diameter inbound metrics.
“Diameter outbound metrics ” describes the Diameter outbound metrics.
“Diameter supplemental metrics” describes the Diameter inbound and outbound supplemental metrics.

row.entry: Number of inbound Diameter messages accumulated since the start of this node.
Average rate of inbound Diameter messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of inbound Diameter messages accumulated since last count interval
Number of Failed IP-CAN Session Establishment Requests
Number of Failed PCEF-Initiated IP-CAN Session Modification Requests
Number of Failed AF Session Termination Requests
Number of Failed Sy Session Establishment Requests
Number of Failed Sy Session Notifications
Number of Failed Sy Session Termination Requests
Number of Failed TDF-Initiated TDF Session Modification Requests
Number of Failed TDF-Initiated TDF Session Termination Requests
Diameter ingress realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Diameter origin realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.

Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available. For example, this could indicate that the Event Trigger was an UE_IP_ADDRESS_ALLOCATE (18)
Number of outbound Diameter messages accumulated since the start of this node.
Average rate of outbound Diameter messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of outbound Diameter messages accumulated since last count interval
Number of Failed PCRF-Initiated IP-CAN Session Modification Requests
Number of Failed AF Session Establishment Requests+Number of Failed AF Session Modification Requests
Number of Failed AF Session Update Requests
Number of Failed AF Session Abort Requests
Number of Failed PCRF-Initiated TDF Session Modification Requests+Number of Failed PCRF-Initiated TDF Session Termination Requests
Number of Failed TDF Session Establishment Requests
Diameter destination realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Diameter egress realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.

Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available. For example, this could indicate that the Event Trigger was an UE_IP_ADDRESS_ALLOCATE (18)
Number of LDAP query attempts accumulated since the start of this node
Average rate of LDAP query attempts (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of LDAP query attempts accumulated since last count interval

entry.p: Whether the search was successful. Will be unmuted by default, but may be muted (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity. Possible values:

row.entry: Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.
Number of inbound HTTP requests accumulated since the start of this node
Average rate of inbound HTTP requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of inbound HTTP requests accumulated since last count interval
The total count of number of http calls where status is 1XX
The total count of number of http calls where status is 2XX
The total count of number of http calls where status is 3XX
The total count of number of http calls where status is 4XX
The total count of number of http calls where status is 5XX
The context root of the HTTP URI address. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
IP address of the source initiating this HTTP request. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.
Number of inbound notificationserver requests accumulated since the start of this node
Average rate of inbound notificationserver requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of inbound/outbound notificationserver requests accumulated since last count interval
OperationName : Always ‘pushNotification/process’ in this SPS version
RequestType : Always ‘INBOUND/OUTBOUND’ in this SPS version
TemplateName : SPS Notification Server's Template name (e.g. Template1)
Channel : Notification Channels (e.g. KAFKA, REST, SOAP, EMAIL, SMS and TCP etc)
Status : Notification INBOUND Status: (OK, SUCCESS, FAILURE, Bad Request), Notification OUTBOUND Status: (SUCCESS, FAILURE, RETRY)
CustomLabel : Notification custom level (e.g. for success - OK, SUCCESS and for failure: "Unable to process your request")
for Notification service: Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
Number of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since this node start
Average rate of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since last interval count
Source IP address. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.
Number of outbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since this node start
Average rate of outbound 5G HTTP/2 requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Number of outbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since last count interval
Destination IP address. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.
Number of incoming messages processed by the SPS ME site routing function
SITE ROUTING application metric counts generated as count per last interval

entry.p: The status/result of the site routing, which contributes to the Decision.
Primary and secondary sites are OOS
Primary and secondary sites are not reachable
No site Id exists for the request
Requests with no site routing resolver
Site routing will not process the request
Site routing decision. Possible values:Requests processed locally: Message sent to a local app for processing
Requests routed to primary: Message sent to the primary SPS ME for processing
Requests routed to secondary: Message sent to the secondary SPS ME for processing
Reject message: message is rejected due to an error in site routing, which could be the target site is OOS, not reachable, a site ID look up failed, or some other failure case.

row.entry: From whom this incoming message is received. The value of the origin host of the Diameter peer that sent this request message, which could be another SPS site or external GW.
The resolved primary Site ID (SPS ME) for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message
The resolved secondary Site ID (SPS ME) for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message

entry.p: The site role of this local SPS ME for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message. Possible values:
Third site (local site is neither the primary nor secondary)

row.entry: Count of the number of rule executions
RULES application metric counts should be generated as count per last interval
Count of the number of overload events
OVERLOAD application metric counts generated as count per last interval

entry.p: Java Heap Memory Usage (State: 85% minor, 90% major, 95% resource critical)

row.entry: Number accumulated since this node start
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
Rating application metric counts generated as count per last interval

entry.p: Diameter ingress realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
Only available in prometheus not in gen3gpp xml files

row.entry: Diameter origin realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.

Rating group. The charging key for the Diameter Credit-Control service identifying a rating group (uniquely identified by the combination of Service-Context-Id and Rating-Group). All the services subject to the same rating type are part of the same rating group.
Service Identifier. The charging key for the Diameter Credit-Control service identifying a service (uniquely identified by the combination of Service-Context-Id and Service-Identifier).

entry.p: Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.

row.entry: Count of the number of PCC Rules provisioned by PCRF to PCEF in a 4G environment.
The name of the PCC Rule.

entry.p: Where, CRN indicates PCC rules dynamically provisioned by the PCRF to PCEF, and CRBN indicates pre-defined group of PCC rules (preconfigured in the PCEF).

row.entry: The layer 2 address (Access Point Name) to which a user is connected in a 4Genvironment.

entry.p: Radio access technology, serving the UE in a 4G environment.

row.entry: Open label where you can provide values in form of "Key Value Pair" basically acting as custom data.
Count of the number of PCC Rules provisioned by PCF to SMF in a 5G environment.
The name of the PCC Rule.

entry.p: Where, CRN indicates PCC rules dynamically provisioned by the PCRF to PCEF, and CRBN indicates pre-defined group of PCC rules (preconfigured in the PCEF).

row.entry: The layer 2 address (Data Network Name) to which a user is connected in a 5G environment.

entry.p: Radio access technology, serving the UE in a 4G environment.

row.entry: Open label where you can provide values in form of "Key Value Pair" basically acting as custom data.

section.title: Entity Count Metrics

row.entry: Total count of entities in db
Currently only the count of Policy Sessions. Prometheus rule to get total count of sessions (equivalent to promql query): entity_count{Type="Session"})
Currently only the count of Devices. Prometheus rule to get Total count of subscribers (equivalent to promql query: entity_count{Type="Subscriber"})

ul.li:
Session
IPCanSession
PDUSession
AfSession
SySession
NchfSession
SdSession

row.entry: Open label where you can provide values in form of "Key Value Pair" basically acting as custom data.

section.note: "session_count_overall" and "subscriber_count_overall" are derived from the base metric "entity_count"

row.entry: Number of device query received from SurePay Index Server
Number of device query received from SurePay Index Server since last count interval
Whether the queried device is found or not. Possible values: Found, NotFound.
Number of Ldap broadcase to SurePay Index Server
Number of Ldap broadcase to SurePay Index Server since last count interval
The operation type. Possible values: Insert, Delete.
Number of inbound NRF messages accumulated since the start of this node. This only specifies the number of NFStatusNotify messages received from NRF.
Average rate of inbound NFStatusNotify messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency of inbound NRF messages during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count) of inbound NRF messages.
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages) of inbound NRF messages.
Number of inbound NFStatusNotify messages accumulated since last count interval.

entry.p: The Component on which the metrics is captured.

row.entry: The Id of the Subscription for which the NFStatusNotify is received from NRF.
The HTTP Status Code for the NFSatusNotify operation.

entry.p: The Custom Label for NRF inbound messages to specify the Status of the request.

row.entry: Number of outbound NRF messages accumulated since the start of this node. This specifies the sum of NFRegister, NFDeregister, NFUpdate, NFHeartBeat, Probe, NFStatusSubscribe, NFStatusUnSubscribe, NFDiscover messages received from NRF.
Average rate of outbound NRF messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency of outbound NRF messages during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count) of outbound NRF messages.
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages) of outbound NRF messages.
Number of outbound NRF messages accumulated since last count interval

entry.p: The Component on which the metrics is captured.

row.entry: The Id of the DiscoveryQuery/NFProfile/Subscription depending on the type of NRF outbound message.
The Id of the NRFServer on which the NRF message is sent.
The HTTP Status Code for the Discovery/Register/Deregister/Subscribe/Heartbeat/Probe operation.

entry.p: The Custom Label for NRF outbound messages to specify the Status of the request. Possible values are:

row.entry: Number of Subscriber Sync Notify requests sent from ME to SM.
Number of Subscriber Sync Notify requests sent from ME to SM since last count interval.

The Subscriber Entity Type.
Possible values:
DEVICE
USER
ACCOUNTGROUP

The Type of Operation performed on the Subscriber Entity for which the Notify is sent to SM from ME.
Possible values:
CREATE
MODIFYDELETE
The Target SM (SiteName) on which the Subscriber Sync Notify is sent.

The Status of the Subscriber Sync Notify sent to SM.
Possible values are:
NOTIFY_SUCCESS (Notification successfully queued at target SM),
NOTIFY_FAILURE (Notification failed at SM, since it could not be contacted),SM_QUEUE_FULL_FAILURE (Notification could not be queued at SM since SM queue was full)
Number of Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgements received from SM at ME.
Number of Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgements received from SM at ME since last count interval.

The Subscriber Entity Type.
Possible values:
DEVICE
USER
ACCOUNTGROUP

entry.p: The Type of Operation performed on the Subscriber Entity for which the Notify is sent to SM from ME.

row.entry:
The Acknowledgement Status received from SM.
Possible value:ACK_RECEIVED

entry.p: The Status of the processing performed at ME after Acknowledgement from SM is received at ME.
SUCCESS (when SyncOp is successfuly reset in the database)
IGNORED (when SyncOp reset is not tried due to inconsistency of SyncOp values received from SM and present in ME database)

table.title: Subscriber Sync Outbound Ecosystem Count Metrics

row.entry: Number of Subscriber Data Record Ecosystems sent from ME to SM in each batch.

row.entry: Number of Subscriber Sync Notify requests received at SM from ME.

entry.p: The Status of the Subscriber Sync Notify received from ME.

row.entry: Number of Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgments requests sent to Target ME from SM after processing at SM is performed.
Number of Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgments requests sent to Target ME from SM after processing at SM is performed since last count interval.

entry.p: The Type of Operation performed on the Subscriber Entity for which the Notify is received at SM from ME.

row.entry: The Target ME on which the Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgement is sent from SM.

entry.p: The Status of the Subscriber Sync Notify Acknowledgement sent to ME.
ACK_SENT (When Acknowledgement is sent successfully to ME)
ACK_FAILED (When Acknowledgement could not be sent to ME)

table.title: Subscriber Sync Inbound Ecosystem Count Metrics

row.entry: Number of Subscriber Data Record Ecosystems received at SM from ME in each batch.

entry.p: The Label for capturing count of SDR Ecosystems.

row.entry: Number of e-commerce API accumulated since the start of this node. This count denotes the total number of requests received at ME
Average rate of e-commerce API messages (per second) during this recent interval at ME. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency of e-commerce API messages during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count) of e-commerce API messages received at ME.
Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages) of e-commerce API messages received at ME.
Number of e-commerce API messages accumulated since last count interval.

entry.p: The Response Code for the E-Commerce API received at ME after processing. This can be any value listed in “RatingEngineResultCodes”. Total 103 values
The Status of the E-Commerce API request received at ME after processing.

row.entry: Number of e-commerce API accumulated since the start of this node. This count denotes the total number of requests received at SM
Average rate of e-commerce API messages (per second) during this recent interval at SM. (calculated sum/interval duration).
Average latency of e-commerce API messages during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count) of e-commerce API messages received at SM.

Number of e-commerce API messages accumulated since last count interval.
The name of the ME on which the E-Commerce API request was sent. If value is NA, then the request could not be sent to the ME due to an exception

entry.p: The Response Code for the E-Commerce API received at ME after processing. This can be any value listed in “RatingEngineResultCodes”.
The Status of the E-Commerce API request received at ME after processing.

row.entry: Info, warning and error raised by Data Refinery nodes
Number of nodes per status, host and configuration
Number of records processed per processing result, host, stream and node
Time (ms) it took for one metric exporter loop to finish

section.title: CDR stream metrics
section.p: All CDR stream metrics have the default labels listed in the following table.

table.title: Default labels for CDR stream metrics

row.entry: Name of the host running the stream instance.
Type of stream (Kafka input, Business logic, Output, Reprocessor).
Prometheus job name (automatically added by Prometheus).
Prometheus target instance (automatically added by Prometheus).
Processing time of the input record batch.
Aggregated Kafka consumer lag for all topic-partitions, i.e. the number of uncollected messages in a topic.
Maximum expired sessions batch aggregation time.
Number of records in a file.
Number of records in a file.
Number of files in the queue.

section.title: Common Redis database metrics for all CDR streams

table.title: Common Redis database metrics for all CDR streams

section.title: Common Jvm metrics for all CDR streams

table.title: Common Jvm metrics for all CDR streams

row.entry: The number of processors available to the Java Virtual Machine.
The "recent cpu usage" for the Java Virtual Machine process.
The "recent cpu usage" for the whole system.

entry.p: The sum of the number of runnable entities queued to available processors, and the number of runnable entities running on the available processors averaged over a period of time.

row.entry: An estimate of the number of buffers in the pool.
An estimate of the total capacity of the buffers in this pool.
An estimate of the memory that the Java virtual machine is using for this buffer pool.
The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

entry.p: id=PS Survivor Space, id=PS Eden Space,
id=Compressed Class Space, id=PS Old Gen

row.entry: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java Virtual Machine to use.

area=nonheap, area=heap, id=Metaspace,
id=PS Survivor Space, id=PS Eden Space,
id=Compressed Class Space, id=PS Old Genid=Code Cache

area=nonheap, area=heap, id=Metaspace,
id=PS Survivor Space, id=PS Eden Space,
id=Compressed Class Space, id=PS Old Genid=Code Cache
Size of old generation memory pool after a full GC.
Count of positive increases in the size of the old generation memory pool before GC to after GC.
Max size of old generation memory pool.
Maximum time spent in GC pause.
Incremented for an increase in the size of the young generation memory pool after one GC to before the next.
